text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with grilled marsala marinated
skirt steak that's right I wanted to
sneak in one more grilling video before
the 4th of July holiday and I know we've
done skirt steak videos in the past but
it's such an amazing cut of meat for the
grill and what makes this recipe a
little bit unusual was that it was
inspired by a chicken parm I head in
Santa Monica a few years ago and while
that may sound a little bit odd on paper
I'm the tongue it was incredibly
delicious so step one you need some
skirt steak I have one whole one that I
actually cut in half before I turn the
camera on so I probably should have
filmed that but it looks something like
this and by the way the only reason
we're cutting that is so it's easier to
fit in a dish to marinade and easier to
work with on the grill and speaking of
marinades that's the next step so we're
gonna transfer that meat into a dish and
then we're gonna start adding our
marinade ingredients and there's really
not that many the first and most
important of which would be their
Marsala wine a beautiful slightly sweet
wine I believe from Sicily so I'm gonna
add a big splash of that and then like I
said this was inspired by a chicken parm
recipe so we need some tomato product
and I was gonna use sauce but then I
decided to go with the ketchup that is a
little more of a sweet sour aspect to it
which works really good in marinades and
then we're also gonna add some rosemary
but not fresh we're gonna use dry
rosemary rosemary is one of those herbs
like tarragon and mint where the dried
version and the fresh version are
actually quite different in flavor
so I'm gonna toss in some dry rosemary
you can totally use fresh it'll work
we're also gonna need some freshly
ground black pepper
a very generous amount of kosher salt or
any salt and then just for a change of
pace we won't put any cayenne pepper but
what we will put is a whole bunch of
finely minced garlic and that's pretty
much gonna be it for the marinade so I'm
gonna go ahead and take the tongs and
mix that all together and while I do
that I will tell you during this video I
make two mistakes one kind of minor one
kind of major and this was the minor one
why didn't I mix the marinade
ingredients first
and then pour it over the meat but if
you just dump everything on top of the
meat like I did and then try to mix it
it's so much more difficult so do as I
say not as I did go ahead and mix those
ingredients in the dish first and then
add your meat okay
but eventually ten minutes and three
curse words later mine was evenly mixed
at that point we're gonna wrap it up and
throw it in the fridge to marinate which
brings us to mistake number two which
could have been a big one but I'm really
not sure and I'll touch on that later
but what happened was I made this in the
morning I was gonna let it marinate all
day and then grill it for dinner which
would have been about eight or 10 hours
of marination time but what happened was
I got hungry and I decided to grill it
for lunch after only a couple hours of
marinating so that's what you see
happening here and while this did come
out incredibly delicious I'll never know
how much better it would have been after
an all-day marinade so as you may have
heard me say before impatience is like
kryptonite to chef so you gotta watch
out for that but anyway threw that on
the grill so what I like to do is let
that sear for a minute and then I like
to give a little wiggle which kind of
lets the meat contract sometimes I get
stretched out when you first put it down
so I do like to move it a little bit
with the tongs and you know we like a
bet a very mature very hot coals for
this
all right thin juicy meat like this we
want it to caramelize and sear very
quickly and then basically we're just
gonna cook it till it shines and I'll
show you what I mean by that in a minute
and of course you can use a thermometer
and go for about 130 internal temp but
when you're dealing with meat this then
sometimes it's tough to get a reading
and also because skirt steak has a very
soft touch it's really difficult to tell
by feel so I really like the shiny
surface system but basically what I like
to do is grill it for about three or
four minutes per side which is gonna be
pretty close and at that point you
should see that surface just starting to
get a little bit shiny is the juices
from the interior there me kind of work
their way up to the surface and this is
kind of what I'm looking for right here
and if you pull it off right there you
should have beautiful juicy pink meat
and of course rarely on a grill are your
pieces of meat the same size and shape
so that thinner one I pulled off first
and I gave that slightly thicker piece
in other minutes and at that point we're
gonna pull that off the grill and head
inside and yes you guessed it we're
gonna let it rest for at least five
minutes all right six or seven is
probably better and while you waiting if
you want to poke it with your finger go
ahead you could also if you want pull
off a meat fiber and eat it and then
speaking of meat fiber once it is rested
and you're about to slice it please pay
attention we have to slice against the
grain
pretty much with all meats but
especially with skirt steak you see the
direction those fibers are running all
right from the foreground to the
background all right we need to make
sure our knife blade is going across
those fibers and if you do cut that
direction your meat will be very very
tender and if you don't it will be very
very chewy still delicious still
flavorful but
very very chewy it would take like three
or four minutes to eat each of those
little pieces and who's got that kind of
time okay so make sure you're cutting
the right direction and as we finished
cutting you can just see how
unbelievably juicy that meat is so we're
gonna slice them up we're gonna throw
that on the plate and because we just
did more of a wet rub on this there
really wasn't a bunch of marinade to
reduce and serve as a sauce but you
definitely want to drizzle over any
juices that accumulate on your plate is
the meat rested and it should be a
decent amount so we'll drizzle those
over and that grilled marsala marinated
skirt steak is done and as I cut in here
for the official taste I couldn't help
once again wondering what would have
happened if I'd let this marinate longer
but even after only a couple hours it
was really really delicious what I like
so much about that chicken parm I had
that inspired this was that little sweet
subtle kick from the marsala in the
tomato sauce and I definitely got a
little bit of that here so I really did
enjoy the flavor and next time I
definitely will let it sit in that what
rub all day maybe depends on how hungry
I am and of course as far as tenderness
goes the ultimate test for skirt steak
can you cut it with just a fork and for
this one the answer definitely was yes I
was gonna say a cut like butter but it
almost cut easier than that alright so
when it comes to grilled skirt steak if
it's not fork tender you're a pretender
but the good news is with a simple
marinade and proper cutting techniques
you should get the exact same results
all right so I really do hope you give
this a try head over to food wishes comm
for all the ingredient amounts and more
info as usual and as always enjoy
you
